Text:
What is HPV and how is it spread?
 
Anal cancer in men and women
Label: Asymptomatic
Question: Does the text indicate HPV infection is asymptomatic?
Guideline: Look for explicit or implicit references indicating that HPV infection has no symptoms.

Text:
What is HPV and how is it spread?
 
Anal cancer in men and women
Label: No Cure
Question: Does the text indicate HPV infection cannot be cured?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly indicate that there is no cure for HPV infection

Text:
What is HPV and how is it spread?
 
Anal cancer in men and women
Label: Sexual Spread
Question: Does the text indicate HPV is primarily contracted through sexual contact?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly indicate that HPV is spread mainly through sexual activity. Reference to non-sexual methods of contractions are not applicable.

Text:
What is HPV and how is it spread?
 
Anal cancer in men and women
Label: Cause of Cervical Cancer
Question: Does the text describe HPV causing cervical cancer?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly indicate HPV can cause cervical cancer. References to other cancers are not applicable.

Text:
What is HPV and how is it spread?
 
Anal cancer in men and women
Label: Cancer Prevention
Question: Does the text indicate HPV vaccination can prevent cancers stemming from HPV?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly state that HPV vaccination can prevent cancers caused by HPV. Focus on vaccination as a cancer prevention tool only regardless of what cancer it is.

Text:
What is HPV and how is it spread?
 
Anal cancer in men and women
Label: Cause of Cancer
Question: Does the text indicate HPV causing any cancer in general?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly state that HPV causes any type of cancer apart from Cervical Cancer. Do not consider statements that only mention cervical cancer. The focus should be on HPV causing cancer in general terms.

Text:
What is HPV and how is it spread?
 
Anal cancer in men and women
Label: Prevent Spread
Question: Does the text indicate HPV vaccination can prevent spreading HPV?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly state that HPV vaccination can prevent the spread of the virus. This includes any mention of vaccination preventing the contraction of HPV, or stopping the development of HPV infection as it indirectly prevents its spread.

Text:
What is HPV and how is it spread?
 
Anal cancer in men and women
Label: Highly Effective
Question: Does the text indicate HPV vaccination as highly effective at preventing HPV and/or related cancers?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly state that the HPV vaccine is highly effective in preventing the virus. References with synonymous words of high effectiveness of HPV vaccine should be captured

HPV types that cause most HPV cancers and genital warts have dropped 88 percent among teen girls and 81 percent among young women.

Text:
Human Papillomavirus (HPV)
 
Human papillomavirus (HPV) is a group of common viruses that can affect both males and females. HPV can be spread by skin-to-skin contact during any type of sexual activity with an infected person, even when no symptoms are present. HPV can cause anal and mouth/throat cancers. It can also cause cancer of the cervix, vulva, and vagina in women; and cancer of the penis in men. Different types of HPV can cause genital warts. The vaccine is routinely recommended at ages 11-12 years to help prevent HPV-associated infections.
Label: Asymptomatic
Question: Does the text indicate HPV infection is asymptomatic?
Guideline: Look for explicit or implicit references indicating that HPV infection has no symptoms.

Text:
Connecticut Department Of Public Healths Comprehensive Cancer Control  Program Calls On Parents and Guardians To Vaccinate Their Kids Against HPV
 
With more than 130 million doses distributed in the United States, as well as 15 years of close monitoring and research, the HPV vaccine is safe and effective and remains the best line of defense against over 33,700 cancers by preventing the infections that cause them. Each HPV vaccine, including 9-valent HPV vaccine (Gardasil 9), has passed through strict safety testing before receiving approval from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA).
Label: Asymptomatic
Question: Does the text indicate HPV infection is asymptomatic?
Guideline: Look for explicit or implicit references indicating that HPV infection has no symptoms.

Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly state that HPV vaccination can prevent the spread of the virus. This includes any mention of vaccination preventing the contraction of HPV, or stopping the development of HPV infection as it indirectly prevents its spread.

Text:
Connecticut Department Of Public Healths Comprehensive Cancer Control  Program Calls On Parents and Guardians To Vaccinate Their Kids Against HPV
 
With more than 130 million doses distributed in the United States, as well as 15 years of close monitoring and research, the HPV vaccine is safe and effective and remains the best line of defense against over 33,700 cancers by preventing the infections that cause them. Each HPV vaccine, including 9-valent HPV vaccine (Gardasil 9), has passed through strict safety testing before receiving approval from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA).
Label: Highly Effective
Question: Does the text indicate HPV vaccination as highly effective at preventing HPV and/or related cancers?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly state that the HPV vaccine is highly effective in preventing the virus. References with synonymous words of high effectiveness of HPV vaccine should be captured

Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly address the safety of the vaccine or mention potential side effects from being vaccinated.

Text:
Massachusetts Partners in HPV Education and Prevention
 
The Boston Area Health Education Center (BAHEC) is a program in the Division of Child and Adolescent Health at the Boston Public Health Commission (BPHC) that introduces high school students to careers in health and public health. In 2016, the BPHC was awarded a grant to implement a service-learning program to increase HPV vaccination rates among students at eight school-based health centers. Twenty-five Boston public high school students were recruited to the HPV Youth Ambassadors Project. The ambassadors created apublic service announcement(PSA) designed to encourage young men of color to receive the HPV vaccination. The theme of the PSA focuses on the concepts of gender norms, goal-attainment and achievement. This PSA is a powerful and unique approach to empower youth to advocate for HPV vaccination and improved health within their communities.
Label: Asymptomatic
Question: Does the text indicate HPV infection is asymptomatic?
Guideline: Look for explicit or implicit references indicating that HPV infection has no symptoms.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that 11- to 12-year-olds receive two doses of HPV vaccine six to 12 months apart.
 
Teens and young adults who start the series later, at ages 15 through 26 years, need three doses of HPV vaccine.
Label: Rec-Children
Question: Does the text recommend HPV vaccination for children?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly recommend HPV vaccination for children (9-15 in age). Ensure recommendations for children are clearly identified and not confused with mere suggestions.

Text:

Teens and young adults who start the series later, at ages 15 through 26 years, need three doses of HPV vaccine.
Label: Rec-Male Femle
Question: Does the text recommend HPV vaccination for both males and females?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly recommend HPV vaccination for both males and females regardless of their age. Look for phrases indicating that vaccination is advised, suggested, or endorsed for both genders.

Text:
Who should not get HPV vaccine?
 
HPV vaccines are safe for children who are mildly ill, like those with a low-grade fever of less than 101 degrees, a cold, runny nose, or cough. People with a moderate or severe illness should wait until they are better. Reference: www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/hpv/public/index.html
Label: Asymptomatic
Question: Does the text indicate HPV infection is asymptomatic?
Guideline: Look for explicit or implicit references indicating that HPV infection has no symptoms.

Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly indicate that there is no cure for HPV infection

Text:

Text:
HPV
 
Human papillomavirus (HPV)is a virus that can have big consequences. HPV can cause certain precancers, cancers, and other diseases that can develop slowly and may not even occur until later in life. Every year in the US, approximately 37,300 people (including women and men) are diagnosed with cancer caused by HPV infection. Cervical cancer is the most well-known cancer caused by HPV; however, it can also cause cancers of the mouth and throat. HPV vaccination series should be started between ages 9 to 26. Those who are ages 27 to 45 years old may decide to get the vaccine based on discussion with their clinician.HPV vaccination is not only about preventing infections, it is cancer prevention.
Label: Asymptomatic
Question: Does the text indicate HPV infection is asymptomatic?
Guideline: Look for explicit or implicit references indicating that HPV infection has no symptoms.

HPV PSA - Dr. Joanie Mayer Hope
Label: Side Effects
Question: Does the text describe safety concerns and potential side effects of HPV vaccination?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly indicate how safe the vaccine is or address the side-effects that could incur from being vaccinated

Text:
HPV Cancer Prevention
 
HPV PSA - Dr. Joanie Mayer Hope
Label: Rec-Children
Question: Does the text recommend HPV vaccination for children?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly recommend HPV vaccination for children (9-15 in age). Ensure recommendations for children are clearly identified and not confused with mere suggestions.

Text:
HPV Cancer Prevention
 
HPV PSA - Dr. Joanie Mayer Hope
Label: Rec-Male Femle
Question: Does the text recommend HPV vaccination for both males and females?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly recommend HPV vaccination for both males and females regardless of their age. Look for phrases indicating that vaccination is advised, suggested, or endorsed for both genders.

Text:
HPV Cancer Prevention
 
HPV PSA - Dr. Joanie Mayer Hope
Label: Stance-Recommend
Question: Does the text recommend HPV vaccination?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly recommend HPV vaccination to any age group/gender instead of suggesting.

Text:
HPV Cancer Prevention
 
HPV PSA - Dr. Joanie Mayer Hope
Label: Stance-Optional
Question: Does the text describe HPV vaccination as optional?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly describe HPV vaccination as optional or a personal choice. Look for phrases indicating that vaccination is not mandatory, such as "can choose," ,"may get vaccinated","is optional," "personal decision," or similar expressions.

Text:
HPV Cancer Prevention
 
HPV PSA - Dr. Joanie Mayer Hope
Label: Source Credibility
Question: Does the text reference reputable sources (e.g. CDC, ACS, AAP)?
Guideline: Relevant statements should mention about HPV/ HPV vaccination and explicitly mention reputable sources such as the CDC, ACS, AAP, or other well-known health organizations.

Text:
The HPV vaccine is an effective way to prevent cancer.
 
Additionally, a 10-year longitudinal study found the vaccine had an 85.6 percent efficacy rate at preventing HPV infection among men.
Label: Asymptomatic
Question: Does the text indicate HPV infection is asymptomatic?
Guideline: Look for explicit or implicit references indicating that HPV infection has no symptoms.

Text:
The HPV vaccine is an effective way to prevent cancer.
 
Additionally, a 10-year longitudinal study found the vaccine had an 85.6 percent efficacy rate at preventing HPV infection among men.
Label: No Cure
Question: Does the text indicate HPV infection cannot be cured?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly indicate that there is no cure for HPV infection

Text:
The HPV vaccine is an effective way to prevent cancer.
 
Additionally, a 10-year longitudinal study found the vaccine had an 85.6 percent efficacy rate at preventing HPV infection among men.
Label: Sexual Spread
Question: Does the text indicate HPV is primarily contracted through sexual contact?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly indicate that HPV is spread mainly through sexual activity. Reference to non-sexual methods of contractions are not applicable.

Text:
The HPV vaccine is an effective way to prevent cancer.
 
Additionally, a 10-year longitudinal study found the vaccine had an 85.6 percent efficacy rate at preventing HPV infection among men.
Label: Cause of Cervical Cancer
Question: Does the text describe HPV causing cervical cancer?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly indicate HPV can cause cervical cancer. References to other cancers are not applicable.

Text:
The HPV vaccine is an effective way to prevent cancer.
 
Additionally, a 10-year longitudinal study found the vaccine had an 85.6 percent efficacy rate at preventing HPV infection among men.
Label: Cancer Prevention
Question: Does the text indicate HPV vaccination can prevent cancers stemming from HPV?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly state that HPV vaccination can prevent cancers caused by HPV. Focus on vaccination as a cancer prevention tool only regardless of what cancer it is.

Text:
The HPV vaccine is an effective way to prevent cancer.
 
Additionally, a 10-year longitudinal study found the vaccine had an 85.6 percent efficacy rate at preventing HPV infection among men.
Label: Cause of Cancer
Question: Does the text indicate HPV causing any cancer in general?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly state that HPV causes any type of cancer apart from Cervical Cancer. Do not consider statements that only mention cervical cancer. The focus should be on HPV causing cancer in general terms.

Text:
The HPV vaccine is an effective way to prevent cancer.
 
Additionally, a 10-year longitudinal study found the vaccine had an 85.6 percent efficacy rate at preventing HPV infection among men.
Label: Prevent Spread
Question: Does the text indicate HPV vaccination can prevent spreading HPV?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly state that HPV vaccination can prevent the spread of the virus. This includes any mention of vaccination preventing the contraction of HPV, or stopping the development of HPV infection as it indirectly prevents its spread.

Text:
The HPV vaccine is an effective way to prevent cancer.
 
Additionally, a 10-year longitudinal study found the vaccine had an 85.6 percent efficacy rate at preventing HPV infection among men.
Label: Highly Effective
Question: Does the text indicate HPV vaccination as highly effective at preventing HPV and/or related cancers?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly state that the HPV vaccine is highly effective in preventing the virus. References with synonymous words of high effectiveness of HPV vaccine should be captured

Text:
The HPV vaccine is an effective way to prevent cancer.
 
Additionally, a 10-year longitudinal study found the vaccine had an 85.6 percent efficacy rate at preventing HPV infection among men.
Label: Number Doses
Question: Does the text describe the number of HPV vaccine doses that are needed?
Guideline: Relevant statements should explicitly address the safety of the vaccine or mention potential side effects from being vaccinated.

Label: Source Credibility

Text:
How well do these vaccines work?
 
The protection provided by HPV vaccines lasts a long time. People who received HPV vaccines were followed for at least about 12 years, and their protection against HPV has remained high, with no evidence of decreasing over time
Label: Asymptomatic
